patient_information: A 22-year-old woman from Ashulia near Dhaka, Bangladesh. She is described as a thin young woman with no other relevant comorbidities reported.
chief_complaint: Profuse watery diarrhoea, with 12 to 15 large-volume stools in the past day, and subsequent unresponsiveness.
history_of_present_illness: Over the past day, the patient developed profuse watery diarrhoea, passing 12 to 15 large-volume stools described as resembling diluted milk or rice water with white flakes. She did not complain of pain and had no fever. Approximately one hour prior to arrival, she became unresponsive, prompting her husband to bring her to the hospital.
exposure_and_epidemiology: The patient resides in Ashulia near Dhaka, Bangladesh. She recently attended a religious festival where water was supplied in large metal containers. Her husband reported that five or six other people who attended the same event were also ill with diarrhoea, suggesting a point-source outbreak from contaminated water.
vitals: On presentation, the patient was afebrile. Her pulse rate was 110 bpm and low volume, and her blood pressure was 90/50 mmHg.
physical_exam: The patient was stuporous, responding minimally to painful stimuli with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 9/15. Signs of severe dehydration were present, including sunken eyes, a dry mouth, and a very slow return on a skin pinch. Her abdomen was scaphoid. The remainder of the systemic examination was normal.
labs_and_diagnostics: Laboratory results on admission revealed hypokalemia (Potassium 3.0 mmol/L), metabolic acidosis (Bicarbonate 11.4 mmol/L), and elevated lactic acid (4.1 mmol/L), creatinine (203 Âµmol/L), and BUN (8.6 mmol/L). Macroscopic stool examination showed liquid, rice-water stool with no fecal matter. A hanging drop preparation of the stool showed small, slender, curved bacilli with darting motility, which was completely inhibited by Vibrio cholerae O1 antiserum. Stool culture grew V. cholerae, which was typed as V. cholerae O1, Serotype Ogawa, biotype El Tor.
differential_diagnosis: The clinical presentation of rapid-onset, profuse, afebrile, watery 'rice-water' stools leading to severe dehydration in an outbreak setting was highly characteristic of cholera. The text indicates the diagnosis was suspected immediately and confirmed rapidly without significant discussion of alternative etiologies for gastroenteritis.
management_and_clinical_course: The patient was immediately started on intravenous rehydration with Ringer's lactate solution, receiving 3 liters in the first hour. Her vital signs improved, with her pulse decreasing to 84 bpm and blood pressure increasing to 100/70 mmHg. After an additional 2 liters of IV fluids over the next 3 hours, she became alert and responsive. She was then transitioned to oral rehydration and given a single 300 mg dose of doxycycline. She was discharged on the third day after her stool consistency returned to normal.
final_diagnosis: The final diagnosis is cholera, a case of severe dehydrating diarrhoea caused by Vibrio cholerae. This was strongly supported by the classic clinical picture of profuse, painless 'rice-water' stools and rapid progression to hypovolemic shock within an outbreak context. The diagnosis was definitively confirmed by stool microscopy showing darting bacilli inhibited by specific antiserum and by stool culture which isolated Vibrio cholerae O1, Serotype Ogawa, biotype El Tor. The patient's dramatic improvement with aggressive fluid resuscitation and doxycycline further supports this diagnosis.
